events.title: Understanding SIP (Systematic Investment Plan)
events.description: SIP means investing a fixed amount regularly (monthly). This builds discipline and uses 'rupee cost averaging'.

teachingMoment.explanation: When you invest the same amount monthly, you buy more units when prices are low and fewer when prices are high. This averages out your cost over time.
teachingMoment.example: If you invest â‚¹10,000/month: At â‚¹100/unit you get 100 units, at â‚¹50/unit you get 200 units. Average cost = â‚¹66.67/unit!

questions.question: What does SIP stand for?
questions.explanation: SIP stands for Systematic Investment Plan - a method of investing fixed amounts regularly (usually monthly) in mutual funds or index funds.

questions.question: What is the main benefit of rupee cost averaging?
options: Averages out purchase cost by buying more units when prices are low
Always buys at the lowest price
questions.explanation: Rupee cost averaging means investing a fixed amount regularly, which automatically buys more units when prices are low and fewer when high, averaging out your cost.

questions.question: What should you do when markets correct or fall significantly?
options: Immediately stop your SIP to prevent losses
Sell all investments and wait for recovery
Stay invested and continue your SIP
questions.explanation: Market corrections are normal. Continuing your SIP during downturns is beneficial as you buy more units at lower prices. Historical data shows markets always recover over the long term.

questions.question: What is the recommended emergency fund size?
questions.explanation: An emergency fund should cover 6 months of expenses, providing adequate cushion for unexpected situations without needing to liquidate investments.

questions.question: For equity investments held for more than 1 year, how much LTCG is tax-free?
questions.explanation: Long-term capital gains (LTCG) up to â‚¹1,00,000 per year are tax-free for equity investments held for more than 1 year. Gains above this are taxed at 10%.

questions.question: What happens to your returns due to compounding over time?
options: They accelerate as returns earn returns
questions.explanation: Compounding means your returns start earning returns, creating an accelerating growth effect. This is why long-term investing is so powerful.

questions.question: What should you do when your income increases?
options: Increase SIP amount to accelerate wealth creation
questions.explanation: Increasing your SIP with income growth helps accelerate wealth creation without affecting your current lifestyle, avoiding lifestyle inflation.

questions.question: What is XIRR?
options: A measure of actual returns considering timing of investments
questions.explanation: XIRR (Extended Internal Rate of Return) calculates your actual annualized returns considering the timing and amount of each investment, making it ideal for SIP evaluation.

questions.question: Why is starting to invest early (at age 25) beneficial?
options: Markets are better when you're young
More time for compounding to work its magic
Investment options are limited for older people
questions.explanation: Starting early gives you more time for compounding. Even small amounts invested early can grow significantly over 30-40 years, making it easier to build substantial wealth.

questions.question: What was the key lesson from the Month 3 market correction in this chapter?
options: Staying invested through volatility leads to recovery and better long-term returns
questions.explanation: The correction in Month 3 demonstrated that while markets can fall temporarily, staying invested and continuing SIP allows you to benefit from the recovery and long-term growth.
